prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Considerations Governing the Protection of Intellectual Property

para.paratext: Jeremy Phillips states that there are essentially four different means of protecting products of the human intellect:
absolute monopoly, which is the right to prevent all other persons from using the property (as in contract);
qualified monopoly, which prevents others from copying or exploiting the work produced (as in copyright);
compulsory licence, which allows others to use the information provided they pay the licence fee to the inventor (as in patent); and
prevention of unfair competition, which enables the inventor to keep others from using the property in an unfair manner (as in protection of confidential information).[1]
J. Phillips, Introduction to Intellectual Property Law (London: Butterworths, 1986), p. 5.
